overview_of_class: Geoffrey Chaucer was a "renaissance man" before the concept was conceived. In the second half of the 14th century, Chaucer served as courtier, diplomat, civil servant, husband, father and spy under three successive English kings: Edward III, Richard II, and Henry IV. However, it is for his poetry that Chaucer is remembered. His Canterbury Tales ranks as one of the greatest poetic works in English. These tales, told in order to win a bet among fictional pilgrims traveling to the shrine of St. Thomas a Becket in Canterbury, represent a summa of medieval literary genres and themes. This course is essentially a "survey" of these tales in which we will discover the richness of Chaucer's literary creation offering various medieval genres: epic, chivalric narrative, fabliaux, allegories, and homilies-and medieval themes-fate and providence; marriage; the role of women in society; sexuality and sin; patientia; and love. The tales will be read in Chaucer's dialect of Middle English, that of the City of London, from which the forms of Modern English are derived. Participants will have the opportunity of discussing the tales as a class and of researching independently the literature, history and culture of Ricardian England.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Previous literature course strongly recommended. Students should have fulfilled the SCS writing requirement or taken equivalent writing courses.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Define the genres in which the tales are expressed.
Describe the common motifs of the tales.
Read the texts in Middle English.
Read texts critically and in depth for meaning.
Express clearly and effectively your opinions on literary topics.
Write a convincing and well-developed argument based on research.
Enjoy reading Chaucer (Yes! I'm a delusional romantic at times!).
